TopicTitle: Has anyone found a live stream for the SpaceX launch on Sunday?

Articles.Content: Or a webcam from Vandenberg or something? Or do I just have to read updates on NSF forums?
There should be a stream on SpaceX's own website; there was last time.
What are they launching? I think your confusing it with the Antares/Cygnus COTS demostration flight also on Sunday.
Don't think so Darth. http://www.spacex.com/missions See the Vandenberg mission?
Oh, I'll also try to watch that one.

Launch date for CASSIOPE is currently TBD, apparantly has been said though it will launch "within a week". There's going to be a hotfire soon but no video, too many people thought the last hotfires were launch aborts apparently so they don't wanna broadcast anything of it.

Hotfire was supposed to be today, but got delayed. There's supposed to be a launch readiness review after the hotfire, which will set the launch date. Launch is currently No Earlier Than Sunday, but could be pushed back due to the hotfire delay.

N.B. The Cygnus 1 launch is scheduled for Tuesday at 1516 GMT (11:16 am EDT + 15 minute window)

Also note that SpaceflightNow does a pretty good job up putting up livestreams for current launches. They usually just grab them from the launch provider's site, but it's convenient to always be able to reach them from one spot. You can go to the launch tracker at the link below and click on the Mission Status Center link for any upcoming launch to go to a launch summary and live feed coverage. (MSC links usually only appear a day or two before launch.)

http://spaceflightnow.com/tracking/

Edited September 11, 2013 by Mr Shifty

Update: Hotfire is on again for today after the scrub yesterday. (Hotfire tests all the rocket systems without actual launch. Rocket is held onto the pad by launch clamps, but fuel load, countdown, engine burn, everything else proceeds like launch.)

Is it still planned for today?

No. Musk's latest tweet suggests the 29th or 30th for a launch date. They still need to do another static fire and the range at VAFB is not available due to Air Force ICBM testing.

Yeah no, anyways, the Air Force did the math, and since the 9.1 has some major changes and a software overhaul, it actually only has about a 50-50 chance of success... Elon knows this, he's taking a risk.

I guess it's pretty smart of them to do a hot fire then. But really, the engines aren't that different right? Same design, 50% higher chamber pressure. heh what could go wrong!

Did the CSA sign a no whining agreement or something? Haven't heard a peep from them and it's their satellite spacex is about to wreck,

Edited September 17, 2013 by nhnifong

Lol, right. I'm not sure about that actually... I think I read something saying that they know the risk too.

Also, they're not streaming the launch anyways.
